linkTarget.anchoringText: North-Komsomolskoye field is located in Purovsky and Nadymsky Districts of Yamalo-Nenets Autonomous Okrug (Fig.1) The field comprises 80 deposits of hydrocarbons, including 28 oil, 6 oil and gas, 12 oil and gas condensate, 14 gas and 20 gas condensate deposits of Upper Cretaceous (PK1, PK102 formations of Cenomanian stage), of Lower Cretaceous (PK12-PK21, AP2-AP11, BP1-BP72, Ach3, Ach4 formations) and the ones of Upper Jurassic (Yu11, Yu2 formations). Prospects of the field development are associated with bringing of hard-to-recover reserves of high viscosity oil PK1 formation of North-Komsomolskoye field.

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Location of North-Komsomolskoye field

formatted-caption.caption-text: Location of North-Komsomolskoye field

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 2 shows geological section of North-Komsomolskoye field.

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: Geological section of North-Komsomolskoye field

formatted-caption.caption-text: Geological section of North-Komsomolskoye field

linkTarget.anchoringText: A pilot project on construction of two long horizontal wells was implemented in 2015 (well A and well B). To solve the above-mentioned issues a decision was made to test new completion technologies for these horizontal wells. Figure 3 shows the profiles of these wells. These wells are horizontal wells with a J-shaped profile with a horizontal end and are 1067 m and 1024 m long respectively. At the same time, the spatial intensity does not exceed 1.5g/10 m till PK1 formation, and does not exceed 1g/10m in the geonavigation mode along the target part of PK1 formation.

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Well A and well B trajectories

formatted-caption.caption-text: Well A and well B trajectories

linkTarget.anchoringText: The lower completion for well A is shown in Figure 4. Two technologies are used to fight against solid particles production: 114 mm multilayer sand screens and gravel packing. Also, the completion includes circulating screens that allow you to create the necessary path of circulation of the carrier brine to create an alpha -wave when gravel packing. A valve was installed inside the circulation screens to insulate the circulation screens after the gravel packing and thus to direct all flows of formation fluids exclusively through the sand screens.

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Well A completion schematic

formatted-caption.caption-text: Well A completion schematic

linkTarget.anchoringText: When the gas passes through the inlet of the control device, the pressure on the disk surface on the flow side is reduced due to the high gas flow velocity. The resultant force acting on the disk shifts it to the inlet, which reduces the flow. When a viscous fluid passes through the inlet, friction losses increase. The force constraining the disk to move to the inlet is decreased, and the inflow is intensified. As a result, more viscous fluids pass through the control device with less resistance compared to less viscous fluids (Figure 5).

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Autonomous inflow control device

formatted-caption.caption-text: Autonomous inflow control device

linkTarget.anchoringText: Completion of well B is shown in Figure 6. The main difference from well A is the absence of gravel packing and division of the well into several sections by open hole water-swellable packers.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: Well B completion schematic

formatted-caption.caption-text: Well B completion schematic

linkTarget.anchoringText: For well A and well B, overall, 6 RESMAN oil intelligent chemical marker systems (RES·OIL) and 6 RESMAN water intelligent chemical marker systems (RES-H2O) were installed into special carrier pup joints with a 127 mm diameter (as shown in Figure 7) between the blank pipe and the perforated shroud. The intelligent chemical marker carrier is open to the external flow in the annulus.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Placement of polymer matrices with the inflow intelligent indicators onto the carriers with protective perforated shroud

formatted-caption.caption-text: Placement of polymer matrices with the inflow intelligent indicators onto the carriers with protective perforated shroud

linkTarget.anchoringText: For this type of study, samples are collected at the intervals of 5 … 60 min during 1-2 days. Measurements of the time period (or volume) required for the indicator material flushing-out from each section of the well (the indicator concentration curve decline rate for each interval) and the comparison of the reservoir model parameters with the actual production data can provide the quantitative assessment for each interval of the horizontal well (Figure 8).

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: The cycle of the inflow profile quantitative assessment

formatted-caption.caption-text: The cycle of the inflow profile quantitative assessment

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 9 shows the trajectory of the well A and the placement of the flow indicator carriers along the wellbore. These systems are sensitive to hydrocarbons (OS) and water (WS) and are numbered from the toe to the heel OS/WS-1 to OS/WS-6, respectively (shown in different colors).

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: The well A trajectory and the placement of the indicator systems

formatted-caption.caption-text: The well A trajectory and the placement of the indicator systems

linkTarget.anchoringText: The studies were conducted in several stages. The first stage was the monitoring of the well cleaning up efficiency during well testing in January 2016. The Figure 10 shows the measurements of the fluid flow rates and the pressure at the ESP inlet as well as the samples collected and analyzed during the cleaning period. During this period, 165 samples (black triangles) were collected, 35 were analyzed for oil indicators (green triangles) and 17 - for water indicators (blue triangles).

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: Measurements in the well A during the well testing period

formatted-caption.caption-text: Measurements in the well A during the well testing period

linkTarget.anchoringText: The results of oil and water indicators response interpretation are provided below and are shown in Figure 11 as a logarithmic scale. This has led to the following conclusions

image-wrap.label: Figure 11
image-wrap.caption: Water inflow indicators (lower graph) and oil inflow indicators (upper graph) responses on a logarithmic scale during the well A clean-up phase

formatted-caption.caption-text: Water inflow indicators (lower graph) and oil inflow indicators (upper graph) responses on a logarithmic scale during the well A clean-up phase

linkTarget.anchoringText: The next phase was the surveillance aimed at quantitative inflow distribution throughout intervals. The objective of this study was to determine relative inflow distribution throughout the zones. For this purpose, advantage was taken of a planned well shut-in from February 2 to February 7, 2016. During the well startup, the well fluid samples were collected on the surface. The Figure 12 shows the measurements of the fluid flow rates and the pressure at the ESP inlet as well as the samples collected and analyzed during the period following the well operation restart after a 5-day shut-in.

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: Measurements in the well A during the period of the well operation restart after the shut-in

formatted-caption.caption-text: Measurements in the well A during the period of the well operation restart after the shut-in

linkTarget.anchoringText: This patented model was verified in a flow-loop test and has demonstrated good practical results. Figure 13 illustrates the mathematical calculations of the model. The fluid inflow from the reservoir in the zone where the intelligent chemical marker system is installed is directly proportional to the k-coefficient of the intelligent chemical marker “charge” concentration decay curve. For a quantitative estimate of the inflow, a Flushout signal is modelled for every measured signal of the indicator system that is as close to the measured value as possible.

image-wrap.label: Figure 13
image-wrap.caption: A simplified illustration of the Flushout model for a quantitative estimate of the inflow

formatted-caption.caption-text: A simplified illustration of the Flushout model for a quantitative estimate of the inflow

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 14 demonstrates the responses from all indicator systems during the well A startup and the results of the Flushout model application to each signal. K-coefficients defining the relative performance (the inflow) in the zone of each indicator system are normalized in relation to the K3 coefficient of the system with maximum performance, which is taken as a unit (K3 = 1.0). Figure 15 shows the relative inflow values for each monitoring point containing the inflow indicators.

image-wrap.label: Figure 14
image-wrap.caption: Flushout model alignment to the measured indicator signals. k-coefficient is proportional to the inflow amount in each zone.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Flushout model alignment to the measured indicator signals. k-coefficient is proportional to the inflow amount in each zone.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 14 demonstrates the responses from all indicator systems during the well A startup and the results of the Flushout model application to each signal. K-coefficients defining the relative performance (the inflow) in the zone of each indicator system are normalized in relation to the K3 coefficient of the system with maximum performance, which is taken as a unit (K3 = 1.0). Figure 15 shows the relative inflow values for each monitoring point containing the inflow indicators.

image-wrap.label: Figure 15
image-wrap.caption: Quantitative estimate of the relative oil inflow at the monitoring points in the well A

formatted-caption.caption-text: Quantitative estimate of the relative oil inflow at the monitoring points in the well A

linkTarget.anchoringText: In view of a short well test cycle, it was impossible to conduct a comprehensive long-term monitoring of the output in a steady-state well operation mode to obtain a qualitative estimate of the zone’s oil productivity changes and the localization of the water breakthrough zones. However, during the initial period of sampling in a steady-state mode, a sudden increase in the response from the OS-6 oil indicator was recorded indicating additional clean-up and increased oil productivity in the heel zone (Figure 16).

image-wrap.label: Figure 16
image-wrap.caption: The effect of additional clean-up in the heel zone (OS-6 indicator)

formatted-caption.caption-text: The effect of additional clean-up in the heel zone (OS-6 indicator)

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 17 shows the trajectory of the well B and the placement of the flow indicator carriers along the wellbore. These systems are sensitive to hydrocarbons (OS) and water (WS) and are numbered from the toe to the heel OS/WS-1 to OS/WS-6, respectively (shown in different colors). B1 and B2 intervals are not equipped with indicators.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The studies were conducted in several stages. The first stage was the monitoring of the well cleaning efficiency during well testing in January 2016. Figure 18 shows the measurements of the fluid flow rates and the pressure at the ESP inlet as well as the samples collected and analyzed during the cleaning period. During this period, 201 product sample (black triangles) was collected, 51 was analyzed for oil inflow indicators (green triangles) and 16 - for water indicators (blue triangles).

linkTarget.anchoringText: The results of oil and water indicator systems response interpretation are provided in Figure 19 as a logarithmic scale. This led to the following conclusions

image-wrap.label: Figure 19
image-wrap.caption: Water inflow indicators (lower graph) and oil inflow indicators (upper graph) responses on a logarithmic scale during the well B clean-up phase

formatted-caption.caption-text: Water inflow indicators (lower graph) and oil inflow indicators (upper graph) responses on a logarithmic scale during the well B clean-up phase

linkTarget.anchoringText: The next phase was the study aimed at quantitative inflow distribution throughout intervals. The objective of this study was to determine relative inflow distribution throughout the zones. For this purpose, advantage was taken of a planned well shut-in from January 19 to January 24, 2016. During the well startup, the well fluid samples were collected on the surface. Figure 20 shows the measurements of the fluid flow rates and the pressure at the ESP inlet as well as the samples collected and analyzed during the period of the well operation restart.

image-wrap.label: Figure 20
image-wrap.caption: Measurements in the well B during the period of the well operation restart after the shut-in

formatted-caption.caption-text: Measurements in the well B during the period of the well operation restart after the shut-in

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 21 demonstrates the responses from all indicator systems during the well B startup and the results of the Flushout model application to each signal. K-coefficients defining the relative linear (per one meter of the length or per one filter with the inflow control devices) performance (inflow) in each monitoring point are normalized in relation to the K6 coefficient with the highest performance, which is taken as a unit (K6 = 1.0).

image-wrap.label: Figure 21
image-wrap.caption: Flushout model alignment to the measured indicator signals. k-coefficient is proportional to the inflow amount in each zone

formatted-caption.caption-text: Flushout model alignment to the measured indicator signals. k-coefficient is proportional to the inflow amount in each zone

linkTarget.anchoringText: K-coefficients defining the relative linear (per one meter of the length or per one filter with the inflow control devices) performance (inflow) in each monitoring point are normalized in relation to the K6 coefficient with the highest performance, which is taken as a unit (K6 = 1.0). Further, for each interval observed, these coefficients are reduced to the interval length according to the number of filters in each zone (Figure 17). Thus, the inflow values for each zone containing the inflow indicators are presented in relation to (normalized) the most productive interval 5 (Figure 22).

image-wrap.label: Figure 22
image-wrap.caption: Quantitative estimate of the relative zonal oil inflow in the well B

formatted-caption.caption-text: Quantitative estimate of the relative zonal oil inflow in the well B
